code: # Flowcharts Supporting flowcharts for the book [Communication systems engineering with GNU Radio - a hands-on approach](https://www.wiley.com/en-fr/Communication+Systems+Engineering+with+GNU+Radio%3A+A+Hands-on+Approach-p-9781394218882). All flowcharts designed and tested with **GNU Radio 3.10**, best displayed with the following options (``View`` menu) active: * Show parameter expressions in block * Show parameter value in block * Show block comments Out of Tree (OOT) block compilation assumes a functional GNU Radio environment, ``cmake`` and GCC, most probably on a GNU/Linux computer. ## Listings: All source codes included in the book are available in the archive: * ``.m`` files are to be executed with GNU/Octave * ``.py`` files are to be executed with the Python(3) interpreter * ``.c`` files are to be compiled with ``gcc`` * ``.cc`` files are to be compiled with ``g++`` * ``.yml`` files are GNU Radio Companion graphical interface description in YAML ## Throttle2 v.s Throttle There are two versions of the Throttle block named ``throttle2`` and ``throttle``. All versions of GNU Radio used by the authors support ``throttle2`` and consider ``throttle`` as deprecated, but in case of error when opening flowgraphs using GNU Radio Companion related to ``throttle2``, please switch to the ``throttle`` branch (``git checkout throttle``) where all ``throttle2`` have been replaced with ``throttle``. ## Feedback Please provide constructive feedback (jmfriedt AT femto-st.fr) on how to improve the book: we will provide updates on the Git repository accordingly. We appreciate comments on Amazon such as "Informative but packed with errors…: Really good information & authors seem to know what they are doing. But the sloppiness is excessive & the lazy mistakes are frustrating." but would appreciate a list of the lazy mistakes so we can update, since the manuscript was thoroughly proofread by the editors and ourselves. A review was published in the october 2025 issue of IEEE microwave magazine.
